title: 110_s1891
content: IMMUNITY FOR REPORTS OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST ACTIVITY OR SUSPICIOUS BEHAVIOR AND RESPONSE. Immunity is granted to individuals who report suspected terrorist activity or suspicious behavior in good faith and based on reasonable suspicion. They are protected from civil liability under any law for making such reports, unless the report is knowingly false or made recklessly. Authorized officials who respond to covered activity with reasonable and good faith actions also have qualified immunity from civil liability. Authorized officials who observe or receive reports of covered activity and respond in good faith are granted qualified immunity from civil liability, in accordance with relevant laws. Additionally, officials not eligible for qualified immunity are immune from civil liability under all levels of law if they act reasonably and in good faith in response to reported activity. In this section, authorized officials are granted qualified immunity from civil liability if they take reasonable action in good faith to respond to reported activity. They are also entitled to recover all reasonable costs and attorney fees if found immune from civil liability. The term "authorized official" is defined in this section. (c) Attorney Fees and Costs.--An authorized official immune from civil liability can recover all reasonable costs and attorney fees from the plaintiff. Definitions in this section include various individuals with security responsibilities in passenger transportation systems. The term "covered activity" refers to any suspicious transaction or occurrence involving a passenger transportation system indicating a potential violation of law related to threats or terrorism. This includes individuals with security responsibilities in passenger transportation systems. The term "passenger transportation" includes various modes of transportation such as public transportation, over-the-road bus, school bus, intercity passenger rail, and passenger vessel. This is in relation to potential violations of law related to threats or terrorism. The term "passenger transportation" encompasses over-the-road bus, school bus, intercity passenger rail, passenger vessel, waterborne transportation service, and air transportation for passengers. This is part of the passenger transportation system involving vehicles. The term "passenger transportation system" refers to entities providing passenger transportation using vehicles. The term "vehicle" is defined in section 1992(16) of title 18, United States Code. This section will take effect immediately upon enactment and applies to activities and claims occurring after that date.
